thread.title_full: Dal can’t fathom interest in ‘irrelevant’ Daisy

title: Dal can’t fathom interest in ‘irrelevant’ Daisy
text:
Dale Thomas been ‘irrelevant’ for three years, contract trigger hype unnecessary, says Nick Dal Santo March 28, 2017 6:52pm Source: FOX SPORTS FORMER 300-game midfielder Nick Dal Santo can’t understand the interest in Dale Thomas’ contract situation, saying the Carlton midfielder has “almost been irrelevant in football circles” for the past three seasons. 
Thomas is in his final season of a four-year contract, but has a trigger — believed to be 15 games this season — that would guarantee him a substantial contract for 2018, despite the Blue’s form and injury issues over his stint at the club. 
Fox Sports reported on Monday that Carlton has already had discussions with Thomas’ management about the midfielder’s delicate trigger clause, as the Thomas camp is determined not to allow the issue to drag on throughout the season. 
But Dal Santo, who played 322 games for St Kilda and North Melbourne, said the kerfuffle around Thomas and his deal was unnecessary, considering the former Pie’s output since arriving at Carlton. 
“I find it interesting that we do speak about ‘Daisy’ as much as we have, because the last three years he’s almost been irrelevant in football circles, just because he’s either been injured or his form hasn’t been up to what has been expected,” Dal Santo told Fox Sports News’ AFL Tonight .

“For someone to have so much spotlight on them after Round 1 is a little bit surprising to me.” 
Thomas kicked one goal from 17 disposals in Carlton’s opening round loss to Richmond at the MCG last week. 
Since crossing over from Collingwood as a high-profile free agent at the end of 2013, Thomas has played 44 of a possible 67 games. He arrived with an ankle problem before encountering a shoulder injury in 2015. 
Consequently, Thomas has been judged negatively due to the contract and the expectations that accompanied it. 
“I just don’t think his football is what it has been and when you get comments about how good he was in 2011, you realised that’s actually six years ago and a lot of things have changed since then,” Dal Santo said. 
“He’s not playing great footy — simple as that. Whether you like him or not, it’s just not up to the standard of what we’ve come to expect.”
